Title: "If employees were treated as well as customers, this job would be awesome"
Pros:
-free meals during training
-free sodas
-they teach you how to upsell
-if you're good at up selling, you can make okay tips in a night
-50 percent off employee meals
Cons:
-Training is a long process. It's paid, but it's tedious. There are written tests and multiple shadow shifts.
-Our restaurant staffs way too many employees at times when they're not needed and as such, it's difficult for us to pay our bills.
-The High 5 Hospitality (sort of like a fancy code of fun rules) says on rule #2 that CPK wants you to be who you (really) are. And yes, the word "really" is in parentheses. The problem is that this only applies to some people. Tattoos are okay, crazy colored hair is okay, but piercings are not. This is hypocritical. It allows some people to be who they (really) are and not others. And it mostly sucks that some of the other servers get to have the physical modifications that make them who they really are, but not all of us. Plus, that damn rule is shoved in our faces repeatedly during training and it's on the wall, so it feels like a smack in the face. I'm a more confident and pleasant server when I feel confident about who I am-and part of that confidence comes from my appearance.
-I've been serving for a couple of years now, and I feel confident in my abilities. However, CPK has a lot of items and modifiers on the menu and in the Aloha computer system, and even for someone with serving experience and experience with Aloha, it takes some time to adjust to a new restaurant. On my first solo shift, I was giving a 5 top on a busy night. As expected, I wasn't able to keep up so well. At the end of the night, I asked to only have 4 tops for just a short while and the on shift manager happily agreed. I've had two more solo shifts since and I've had 5 tops both nights. For a company so focused on customer service and service details, there's a huge lack of awareness of what's possible for a newbie to the restaurant to even do.
Advice to Management:
If employees were treated as well as customers, this job would be awesome. It's too difficult to pay my bills with this job-even if I get tipped 20 percent with every bill. There are too many employees scheduled at a time and it's costing all of us money. We're all hurting financially. I'm still very new at this job and even with serving experience, it's crazy to give my a 5 top on my first solo shift. That makes no sense! For a company so utterly focused on top notch customer service, it must be clear that it's nearly impossible for a new hire to serve 5 tables on a busy night with great service details and a smile. A person needs at least a shift or two to adjust to four tables.

Also, the High 5 Hospitality is hypocritical. I'm sorry to say it, but it is. #2 on the list says that CPK wants employees to be who we (really) are. But this seems to only apply to some people. Tattoos are okay (some tattoos), crazy colored hair is okay, but piercings are not. This is hypocritical. It allows some people to be who they (really) are and not others. And it feels terrible that some of the other servers get to have the physical modifications that make them feel confident about who they really are, but not all of us get to have that. Plus, that rule is everywhere (on the walls, on the tests, etc.), so it's impossible to ignore. I'm a more confident and pleasant server when I feel confident about who I am-and part of that is my appearance. As long as my hygiene is good, I should be allowed to be who I really am, right?

Title: "Hostess"

Title: "Designed for college students."
Pros:
- Flexible schedules. (Mobile app is available to see work schedules and/or make requests off.)
- Relaxed management/work environment for the most part.
- Great co-workers, very hospitable environment, and decent client base.
- No serving experience necessary to get hired.
- Server side work is very easy compared to other chain restaurants.
- Food and drink menus are easy to learn.
- Excellent for making quick cash.
- Working shifts normally consist of 4 hours.
- Can cross train into any position.
- Yearly bonuses ($350) are paid to full time employees.
Cons:
- Rewards sign-ups are mandatory and no compensation is paid regardless of the amount.
- Management will purposely understaff in order to cut labor costs and will also send cooks home early, leaving only one in charge of four separate stations. Tipped employees pay the price for it.
- Only one bartender is scheduled per shift and are given way too much responsibility. They are required to not only bartend and wait tables but to also work at take-out which is a separate job (due to the high volume of orders that always come in) and to also man the expo (the cooks job to manage food going out) which is another separate job. It affects the bartenders tips.
- No barbacks are ever hired and take-out positions are only filled 4 shifts out of 14 shifts in order to cut labor costs.
- Again, in order to cut labor costs, they make the busser do the dishwashers job for the same buss boy pay.
- They are incredibly quick to hire and overstaff hosts/hostesses compared to every other position combined.
- No career advancement or opportunities offered.
Advice to Management:
- Put employees before profit.
- Expand employee benefits and make them be known.
- Speed of service and customer satisfaction can drastically improve if the company stops being so cheap when it comes to labor costs.

Advice to Management: Have understanding of that your employees are your biggest asset to company

Title: "Best Job Ever!"
Pros: Great teamwork, awesome/ beneficial experience & lots of benefits. A lot of staff grows within the company. This is a great company to work for! I started working as a host and now I am serving and temporarily at the Corporate office, hoping to one day be at the Corp. office permanently.
Cons: I do not have any cons.
Advice to Management: Keep on being awesome!

Title: "Not the best place anymore"
Pros: Felt like a family. Very flexible with time off and transferring to a different store.
Cons: not all stores are created equal. Some places are amazing to work and others were not. The company as a whole has gone down the hill in the last 2 years. No money and bad leadership.
Advice to Management: Lead by example. The regional manager needs to not be a dictator and realize happy employees make great customer service.

Title: "Takeout"
Pros: Discounted food, potential for good tips, closes pretty early for a restaurant so having a social life is possible (10pm)
Cons: low pay if your not a server, management switches. Most jobs in the kitchen are very laborious in nature
Advice to Management: hear what employees have to say and try to make changes that are good for the restaurant culture

Title: "Restaurant Support Center"
Pros: Absolutely LOVE working in this place! The energy, culture and excitement surrounding the transformation of the company is exhilarating! Great teamwork, lots of fun and a ton of opportunities for innovation. The CEO is so awesome! He is always walking around, saying hi to people, walking in your office and sitting down having casual conversations. You forget he is running to whole company. He wants your opinion and cares about what is going on in your life. This place has everything I love, fun, food, culture and leaders who get it!
Cons: Location. It is located in Playa Vista so the traffic and drive is not fun. But it has been worth it so far!
Advice to Management: Keep doing what your doing - focus on the people and keep it fun!

Title: "Server - Best job I've ever had"
Pros: CPK has a fun, laid back atmosphere for the most part. Hours are pretty flexible when there is a full staff of servers; most people are understanding and willing to swap shifts if something comes up. Management knows their jobs and cares for everyone under them, from cooks to hosts. Managers will help to make us as much money as possible, from running food to calming down customers. That in turn helps us to give each and every customer a positive experience. Pay for the amount of hours worked is AMAZING compared to every other serving job I've had. Overall: workers that care about one another like a family and do things together outside of work, great pay, and flexible hours (which is perfect for someone like me putting themselves through college)
Cons: One of my biggest complaints is Pizza Dough sign ups. We are told that we need to reach X amount of Pizza Dough sign ups each shift and that it is part of our job to sell this to customers. While I understand that it's to convince customers to want to come back, I feel like we are having to berate these customers. From what I understand, if we continuously do not hit our quota, we will have to go to meetings on how to sell this. If this fails, they would let us go. Plan to work most holidays (not just exclusive to CPK, however).
Advice to Management: While I understand that Pizza Dough gives to the guests, the way in which we are made to push them on the guests makes me a bit bitter about it.

Title: "lots of management issus"
Pros: If the store is one that generates a lot of sales, tips are good.
Cons: Things may have changed since it's been quite some time since I worked there, but when I was there, there were lots of management issues. The company had been in trouble for making workers work through lunch without pay and was forced to pay them back, the management was micromanaging much for for no reason and was setting quotas for selling their new products. There were also issues about long-time employees getting their hours cut.
Advice to Management: Don't micromanage as much. California Pizza Kitchen is supposed to have a "laid back" atmosphere and forcing servers to constantly "push" products at customers because they're trying to meet quotas creates a less comfortable work atmosphere and dining experience for customers instead of just letting the server make genuine suggestions.

Title: "cpk work experiance"
Pros: flexible hours good job to have during school
Cons: food service, people are grumpy when they are hungry

Title: "If you like working long hours great job"
Pros: Great food great menu, The training is great and expectations are high.
Cons: Managers are expected to work 60-70 a week and you are shunned if you try to go home on time. Very Micromanaged, Owner told managers the new work/life balance is liking your job...

Title: "Humble bartender's two cents."
Pros: Busy store, good money, great hours.
Cons: Lack of communication on management level. Stereotypical corporate philosophy meaning bottom line is money. Everything is regulated. No rewards or incentives for excellent work. Employees treated as bodies instead of people. Lack of accountability overall.

Title: "Mixed"
Pros: We get 15% in tips. Some of the regulars are really kind,and co workers are really good at working as a team.
Cons: This company asks too much of their employees but they wont reward us for any of the things they ask us to do.Ive never seen a restaurant try that hard to have good cutomer service all the extra stuff in non sence.

Title: "Waikiki CPK"
Pros: More than enough hours to go around for cooks...
Cons: poor management and unrealistic expectations

Title: "It was OK"
Pros: Great money, well depending on location. You get to develop relationships with customers. Had SOME good managers
Cons: Very pushy incentives per management, especially with the new company changes. Constantly working double shifts due to lack of staff. Management also played favoritism, and when employees tried to complain on the CPK hot line, we were basically told that theres nothing they could do because there weren't enough complaints
Advice to Management: Treat employees fairly in any and every aspect of the workplace

Title: "Server"
Pros: I loved working at cpk! good fun good people
Cons: didnt make enough money, some customers suck

Title: "Manager"
Pros: Very good reputation and concept. Good benefits.
Cons:
Since being bought out, CPK has put employee morale and well being on the back burner, no pun intended. Long, long hours for poor pay for managers. CPK used to be a great place to work. No
More. The place will suck the life out of you.
Advice to Management: Put employee well being back as a priority instead of selling them out to make a profit. Stop cutting employee perks and incentives and expecting more for less pay. Stop burning your managers out for short term gain as in the long run high turnover costs the company more money. CPK used to be a great place to work. It's horrible now.

Title: "Fun and Easy Job for Students"
Pros: ANYONE can be a server. It is the perfect way to make quick money without having to work ridiculous hours-especially while in school. CPK had a very fun work environment that was laid back for the most part. Once better management took over, everything improved drastically. There is no longer an extensive sequence of service that needs to be followed (there was in previous years, but it was thrown out). If you are an outgoing and fun person, this job is a breeze.
Cons: Things can be a bit stressful when the restaurant is busy, but every job can be stressful at times. It's easy to leave work at work.
Advice to Management: Keep it up! My managers were great leaders and friends.

Title: "Server/Bartender"
Pros: Great place to get experience if you've never served or worked in food before.
Cons: Sometimes management is unorganized and very hesitant to give raises to deserving staff.

Title: "Server"
Pros: Friendly place, you get to know a lot of interesting people who are willing to help you anyway they can
Cons: job is not always secure, it can be physically demanding, very fast pace, you have to get along with a lot of people with different (and sometimes crazy) personalities

Title: "A lot has gone downhill"
Pros:
Flexible hours/schedule
Chill people
Busy but manageable
Good experience if you are just starting out in the food industry
People are mostly helpful
Cons:
Managment
Management is horrible, no organization or consistency. Every manager tells you something different. Gm is never there and usually has nothing but negative things to say even though he's not around to see you perform. Lazy managers. They are what make the job horrible and unenjoyable. If management can get their stuff together it'd be a better place to work.
Advice to Management:
Value your employees and treat them well.
Communicate with other managers and us and provide consistency and be understanding of what we are dealing with instead of just trying to just get rid of the issue by agreeing with the customer.

Title: "hostess"
Pros: flexible hours. get to work with various personalities and meet unique people.
Cons: very fast paced environment. management is somewhat unorganized.

Title: "Cpk server"
Pros: Easy and flexible. Great for working part time. Some people were able to support their families.
Cons: Management didn't care about their employees. They would side with customers on ridiculous reasons.
Advice to Management: Please take care of your employees

Title: "it's o k"
Pros:
My coworkers are all really friendly and the managers are really flexible with your schedule
It's a pretty easy job
Cons: I don't get paid much hourly but I get tips so it kind of evens it out

Title: "Ups and Downs"
Pros: Easy going, relaxed atmosphere. Good money when busy and depending on the location. My particular location has a great work atmosphere amongst the servers. One of the reasons I stayed for so long.
Cons: Change in management is changing the quality of service and overall happiness of the staff. While I understand that as a new manager/gm it is an adjustment, some if the changes are nit-picky and unnecessary. Some things instituted by the new management has made servers worried for their job. Another issue is the over staffing of weekends. A three table section is not enough to sustain a person who serves soley. Hence on lookout of another job.
Advice to Management: CPK never has a daily special. While we try to be above T.G.I. Friday tier, drink specials would draw in a daily crowd and drive up sales.

Title: "The Best among corporate chains IMO"
Pros: Great company. Among corporate chains, it doesn't get any better. Wonderful support staff including not only the regional directors, but also the COO and CEO who are very involved with daily operations.
Cons: Shocker...no weekends free. Also, plan to work most national holidays.

Title: "restaurant manager"
Pros: many great benefits and coworkers
Cons: manager scheduling creates poor quality of life
Advice to Management: create permanent or rotating schedules to improve quality of life

Title: "Great company to grow with"
Pros: A company that genuinely cares about its people, product, and brand awareness. Lots of opportunities to grow within the company and because it is currently undergoing massive expansion, there are lots of chances to get into the new restaurants on the ground level. Great benefit packages.
Cons: As a restaurant manager (much like at most other restaurants), there are long hours and no set 9-5 schedule. Weekends are a must and time off is often difficult to accommodate.
Advice to Management: Keep the focus on the people. This company has great, loyal people who have worked hard for this company for many years. They are very deserving of the kind treatment that has always been a focus in the ROCK philosophy.

Title: "server"
Pros: Flexible Hours, Friendly Managers, Easy Going Environment, Casual Uniform, Gain customer service knowledge
Cons: Not enough hours, Co-Workers often times are out for thier own benefit, Weekdays are dead, Training is shoddy, Lazy co-workers, Serving parties of kids (no tips)
Advice to Management: Show new servers how to be perform thier job, Be on the floor more often, Make a decent break room

Title: "Fun job for extra cash"
Pros: Great coworkers, pretty good hours for the restaurant industry, team mindset
Cons: When new CEO took over things went downhill. They were trying to cut costs and it negatively impacted workers.

Title: "Decent enough for a corporate chain"
Pros: There's a steady clientele, and most people are pretty familiar with the brand so there's a level of confidence in the products that's helpful. Most FOH employees work part time so if you need a specific day off there's usually someone who's willing to take your shift and help you out. If you work more than a certain number of hours per year, you get a bonus on your hiring anniversary. If you want to advance, the company makes that pretty easy. They like to promote from within when possible.
Cons: It's a corporate chain, so they have rules and regulations out the ying-yang. There's not a lot of flexibility when it comes to most things, and that isn't going to change no matter how much the employees might want it to. And since they're in the business of making money, a lot of those rules and regulations are to the detriment of their employees. Don't ever forget that you're replaceable. Part of the problem here is that the rules and regulations come from the corporate office, and 90% of the rule makers haven't worked a shift in years.

Title: "Fun"
Pros: Fun and fast paced. quick money
Cons: you are a server and depending on location the guest are cheap
Advice to Management: don't talk to employees like childeren

Title: "Well run company with lots of opportunity for advancement."
Pros: Great good, great benefits, lots of opportunity for career growth
Cons: Horrible work life balance if you're in management. Working 60hrs a week is a common and expected thing.
Advice to Management: Find a way to have more work life balance or managers will keep leaving. Allow us to have more staffing because if we want to be the best in the industry, it takes more people to do it.

Title: "Downhill trend"
Pros: None anymore. The food is alright?
Cons: Regional managers have put into place stringent standards a server has no control over (table turn time, e-mail sign up quotas) that if we can't meet then we lose shifts. Store level managers are useless. 4 table sections even on a slow monday lunch. Used to be such an amazing company to work for and the HR departments wants nothing to do with us as employees.
Advice to Management: Listen to your servers and stop applying across-the-board policies to every location. A business degree doesn't teach you street smarts.

Title: "Started out excited,ended unsatisfied"
Pros: Great co workers,they made the job Barrable. Free food during training time. Big food discounts.
Cons: Management suck,VERY understaffed. Double shifts, no breaks. They don't care about servers.
Advice to Management: Stop talking to your servers like crap.

Title: "Money is good, but management is the worst part about this job."
Pros:
Easy money
Little side-work
Fun co-workers
The hours are very flexible.
Cons: Management, management, management. If they can fix this, I would love working here.
Advice to Management: Fix the restaurant management.

Title: "Great place to work"
Pros: Managers are usually well-trained and are very nice. They can be very flexible with your hours and are very considerate when it comes to last-minute changes, as long as it's for a good reason.
Cons: We always run out of bread and it compromises service
Advice to Management: Make more bread

Title: "Going downhill"
Pros: Plenty of opportunity to cross-train (server/bartender/host/take out). Lots of opportunity for promotion to manager from hourly employee, if you so desire.
Cons: Too much change at the leadership level leading to inconsistencies at the restaurant level. Benefits sliding downhill fast. Long-term employees had their pay and benefits cut, food that used to be deeply discounted for hourly employees is now 50% off, which is still quite expensive.
Advice to Management: Treat your hourly employees with dignity, as was done in the Rick-and-Larry-era, and the guests will return. People dine out for the experience as much as the food, and unhappy staff leads to unhappy guests.

Title: "Great place to work"
Pros: The people I work with are great. Management is good as well.
Cons: Clientele that comes in often assume to not tip well because it is corporate. Company as a whole continuously changes uniforms requiring you to buy new ones.
Advice to Management: Remain consistent in what needs to be done

Title: "Great job"
Pros: Good money. Flexible schedule. Awesome friends
Cons: Food gets old. Too corporate. Management sucks

Title: "Before the Golden Gate capital buy-out the company felt more about people, now it feels all about money."
Pros: Food is great and fresh. They have high standards for that. They have a good reputation.
Cons: Management lacks passion for the industry in WA. Senior Management is not interested in developing those committed to the company and continued to hire externally. Had a sense of discrimination within the company. Good work went unnoticed unless you pointed it out.
Advice to Management: Promote those who love the brand and committed to the company. You cant teach that! Passion and attitude is everything in this industry!

Title: "25 years in Hospitality Industry, this is the worst company I've ever worked for."
Pros: flexible hours part or full time
Cons: Management's only concern is number crunching. Managers' style is consistently pessimistic. There was never a positive word of encouragement. The more an employee gave, the more was expected. Never a "thank you", never a "good job!"

Title: "Good community of employees"
Pros: The employees are the awesome and the managers really work with the employees to make sure they're happy. Most of the employees are students so the managers really work with us to make our schedules fit.
Cons: The general manager wants us all to be able to express ourselves and yet has us all wear the same color shirts, hide our piercings and not let us dye our hair.

Title: "Use to be one of the most dynamic places to dine and wrk for but my, my, my how have times changed tor the worst. So sad"
Pros: Flexible hrs, great co-workers and decent local management. I started as a server while in grad school: money was great and the we had organic joy not corporate mandated -- think high five -- friendliness.
Cons:
Since Golden Gate.
vacation hour program for non-salary ppl replaced
health insurance sucks p.s. stop blaming Obama for this change
employee benefits slashed -- we pay a great deal more for employee meals
employees treated not as valued teammates or partners, now they are throw away parts
T/o people are expected to work harder with less pay
New Regional directors suck -- very rude, self-important and ineffective.
work environment very stressful
Advice to Management:
Where do I start? The new owners -- Golden Gate (think Romney and Bains corp.) have for the most part greatly damaged a formerly great brand in the name of making profits for the top brass. Cheaper ingredients, smaller portions and different recipes have decreased guest food satisfaction and return business. Corp. knows this but still blame FOH staff for failure to meet sales projection.

Second, mid-management purge -- gms, rd's and regional veeps -- have led to new mid-managers who are clueless in understanding the CPK brand or culture. However, since they have titles the behave as arrogant know-it-alls. They are strongly lacking interpersonal skills, hence, their communication is extremely condescending.

On the corp. level the are floundering big time. They try so many Johnny-come-lately and ineffective promotions that guest dread. A la Bains corp, they know how to ruthlessly reap profit but they are clueless in how to operate a restaurant. And on the corp level as well, they have a tin ear. They created a new narrative and despite facts-on-the-ground saying otherwise, they are rigidly sticking to what ain't working.

Bottom line: You may have needed new innovations to keep the old CPK afloat but you medicine is making CPK sicker. Please sell to competent management team. And stop creating G J Hart cult of personalities mini me's

Title: "Used to be a great company to work for..."
Pros: Like any restaurant it depends on where you work and the staff it employs. My experience was ever changing management of four GMs in the last five years.
Cons: Product is too niche and outdated.
Advice to Management: Doing a better job in menu development and focusing on less pizzas and the cuisine around it.

Title: "At first I really enjoyed working with this company but some of the employees are extremely difficult to work with."
Pros: Money, flexible schedule, some great people
Cons: If you have a problem with a coworker, the management doesn't do anything....so better go to corporate.
Advice to Management: Just because some one has worked for the company for a longer period of time, doesn't mean they should be able to talk down to others and bully.

Title: "Server"
Pros: The tips are sometimes pretty good
Cons: A ton of the employees and management are very umprofessional at times.

Title: "Great Company!"
Pros: Great work life balance, easy money, mall hours instead of late restaurant hours, company values are great!
Cons: Dealing with customers can be challenging but as long as you have a great team you can make it through just fine!
Advice to Management: Do contests to drive server sales!

Title: "I love working at my local CPK!"
Pros: Interview process was easy, they gave thorough training, within 3 months I was promoted from server to bartender (with no previous experience) and I love the team we have!
Cons: Sometimes the mood of a few people trump the positive work environment and there are a few lazy people that I wish management would get involved and make them work or send them home.

Title: "Slow to promote within"
Pros: The staff was great to work with. Everyone was in college or around the same age
Cons: Managers promise promotion but do not follow through
Advice to Management: Keep to your promises of promoting within

Title: "Great experiences with CPK"
Pros: Great training process. Managers make sure you know what you need to know before starting. Haven't had one bad managerial experience in a year of working. Employees are great as well.
Cons: The brand is trying to recover from a string of bad years so the expectations can seem a little high at times. Upper management pops in and out to check up on things and really puts pressure on the staff.

Title: "Decent job"
Pros: Tips are good on busy nights
Cons: Hard to pick up shifts w/o seniority

Title: "Good situation for host"
Pros: free meals each shift (not sure if they do this anymore)
Cons: turnover, management doesn't care about the people

Title: "Great Work Environment"
Pros:
A great serving Job with out ever having to sing happy birthday to anyone. Management is pretty trusting, as a server only you know the real need of your patrons so management lets you make most of the important decisions when it comes to comping, birthdays, coupons, gratuities, etc.... all they do is provide the swipe minimum questions asked. best of all they try to maintain a laid back California Atmosphere. Did I mention you Don't sing happy birthdays here!!
sales contest are great and fun. and every once in a while you get cash prizes just for memorizing the company mission statement. so being bilingual is a plus. if you work hard you will be noticed, i went from Dishwasher to server in a few months, training is top notch.
Cons: Employees, try your best to not get involved romantically with other employees whether from BOH or FOH. The last thing you want to lose you job over is a scandal. also Do not ever come to work high. or jokingly reassure a customer that you did not spit in his food. Cause you will get fired!! Basically use you common sense.
Advice to Management: Managers Please stay out of the kitchen on Packed out nights. If it takes you 5 minutes to make a salad on a slow shift, nobody wants you making their salad, pasta, or pizza on a busy night, more likely that your services are needed out on the floor

Title: "Rude management"
Pros:
Flexible schedule
Tip outs
Friendly co-workers
Short and/or long shifts depending on your needs and availability
Opportunities for re-location
Cons:
Rude and condescending management
They throw you out in to the stampede of guests by yourself on day one

Title: "Great company to work for in this industry!"
Pros: It is as laid back as a restaurant can be. The company wants you to be your unique self. I got a bonus for being there a year. Scheduling is flexible and easily accessed via the internet. Also, at my location the latest we stay open in 9:30!
Cons: The only complaint I have isn't something the company can control. It is an entry level job where a lot of first time employees start their working experience, therefore they just don't care about their job performance.
Advice to Management: Maybe give more evaluations of foh staff with a small bonus or raise as an incentive to do well. I'm talking as little as free movie tickets. A little goes a long way.

Title: "Working at CPK has taught me how to deal with every type of customer there is. It keeps me on my toes."
Pros: Intense training, prepares you to serve at any restaurant
Cons: Can be very stressful. Need to increase wait times for customers to avoid triple seating a server's section.
Advice to Management: relax a little

Title: "New ownership and management are a joke..."
Pros:
Was an outstanding company prior to its sale to Golden Gate.
They had an outstanding culture and sense of teamwork.
Cons:
GJ Hart has proven to be a "one trick pony" who has taken a sucessful concept and culture and tried to turn it into another Texas Roadhouse. What an overrated, egotistical clown. After cleaning house he has brought in more and more people from Texas Roadhouse as if that will save his bacon.
Hopefully, Golden Gate will see the light and dump the mess he has created.
Advice to Management: Punt...

Title: "Wonderful Company, Great Culture"
Pros: The environment is great and actual chain food that's good. Promotions are frequent. Great first place to work. Discount food.
Cons: inexperienced management, constantly changing menu, long training program
Advice to Management: keep it consistent. try hiring a team instead of several good individuals

Title: "No support for management"
Pros: Competitive salary and benefit package
Cons:
Company is owned by a private equity firm- not a restaurant group
Constant management turn over
Much of the original CPK is gone- new company has slowly laid off long term employees at the corporate level
Long hours
Sales based bonus system
Advice to Management: The term jack of all trades, master of none applies here. When you roll out several different initiatives all at the same time- it is counter-productive. Also- you have many long term back of house employees who are very over-paid and send labor percentages soaring. To compensate- you cut labor dollars from the front of house- then you wonder why your guests do not come back. You need to start listening to your managers and supporting them- constantly training new ones that don't last must be getting very expensive for you.

Title: "what you see is what you get"
Pros: Staff front and back house are mostly fun to work with. upper management works hard and are knowledgeable. computer system is simple to learn. food is pretty good to good. drinks good. I'm a server and management works really hard to work with my availability
Cons: front of the house is constantly reminded to push loyalty cards, promotions and use a "kinda" script when approaching guests. we're also pushed to ask guests to fill out surveys online to raise our satisfaction ratings in the eyes of corporate.

Title: "Server/ Trainer"
Pros: Great people and a fantastic culture. Flexible on schedule, sections and time off.
Cons: eat too much of their food and gain weight.

Title: "Changing company, mostly for the better."
Pros: In the past company spent outrageous amounts of money. They are working on bringing thier spending back in line with the rest of the industry. Long time employees hate it. But no one pays hourlie what these long term employees are making. Overall these are changes that need to be made. Company has tons of potential.
Cons: They are making some mistakes along the way. But, they are quick to admit it and adjust. Still haven't figured out exactly what they want to be. Many long term managers have left; many, many new managers in the system.

Title: "it's ok"
Pros: this job is ok make most money on tips
Cons: dont give you a lot of hours

Title: "Horrible compensation by no fault of the company. The guest's who dined at the location I worked for barely tipped for their pre-packaged out of a bag food. (Understandably so.) Outdated system used to seat guest's (like Dark ages outdated), and extensive training on irrelevant information that was not actually relevant or helpful on the job."
Pros: It is a job. If you are unemployed it can offer you some sort of compensation.
Cons: Strange corporate culture. Not a team environment like they advertise. There was a click of employees with the most seniority, like in most restaurants, however it was just sad to watch because they valued such a horrible job so highly. They definitely have their employees drinking some kind of cool-aide.

Title: "Just no."
Pros: Fun work environment, nice people, we all became like a family.
Cons: Not very much proper training, things change far too often, shady pay cuts, this job becomes your life if you need the money.
Advice to Management: Get on the same page, train us properly, make better hiring choices.

Title: "Be part of a family."
Pros: At CPK, it was great to work alongside people that were just as friendly and awesome to be around - including your general managers and those above you. Everyone worked together to really reach the peak at where we wanted to be. The food is phenomenal, and as menus roll out, you get to taste the new items without buying them which gives you an opportunity to sell, sell, sell.
Cons: There's a relatively small staff. People don't really want to pick up your shifts, even though you are constantly picking up theirs when they need the assistance.
Advice to Management: I think it would be great to implement even more extensive training that would go into all of the positions in the restaurant, even if you are only going to be front of the house.

Title: "Good people, evolving company, high demands"
Pros: Great coworkers, benefits were good
Cons: high demands, constant changes, menu updates multiple times a year

Title: "wasting my life away"
Pros: Flexible schedule, ability to travel, relocate, move up in the company
Cons: pay, no more benefits, no more free food, no more vacation pay, high turnover rate, both management and staff
Advice to Management: It's quality not quantity

Title: "Salary"
Pros: Good corporate structure and pay.
Cons: Not the same culture under new owners
Advice to Management: Culture!

Title: "Had great opportunities but the politics were hard to get past"
Pros: While under the original owners, I took advantage of the opportunities within the company and moved up were I could. From server to bartender to in store trainer to corporate trainer to DSL (Dining Shift Leader). The best part was being a corporate trainer or "Opening Team Trainer". Compensation was decent, perks of good health insurance and stipends while traveling were great. I made good money and while working full time with the company, bought a car, a house and went back to school.
Cons: The politics is what really gets you. I stopped moving up in the company and working as a DSL and Opening Team Trainer while the original owners were still in place. Too much sexual harassment, gossiping, backstabbing and the lack of education in many individuals made it a tough environment to succeed in. I did work under the new owners, but only as a server and bartender part time; therefore, I can't really comment on how things have been since the takeover.
Advice to Management: Listen to your employees, especially ones that have been there a long time and do a good job. They care about their work, the company and want to be successful so listen to their concerns, take their advice and ideas and show that you care about them.

Title: "Amazing"
Pros: Great management team and co-workers
Cons: Not enough hours to go around sometimes

Title: "Unprofessional"
Pros: Great pay..great culture in theory. Great operating systems. Diverse culture, opportunity for advancement
Cons: Favoritism ... Had gm sleeping with assistant manager. When I started to question , after 7 yrs employment I was asked to leave due to gm feeling uncomfortable???? Gj... I suggest you stop trying to reinvent and get back to basics
Advice to Management: Follow policy.. Don't look the other way when someone breaks rules just to be nice. If I was more vindictive I would have had a great law suit!!

Title: "Great for part-time work, but seriously poor management"
Pros: Extremely laid-back, great food plus employee discounts
Cons: Laid-back attitude to a fault. Poor management/leadership. Incompetent managers.

Title: "Hard Worker? Go somewhere else."
Pros: The food is good and they have gone back to encouraging individuality.
Cons: Managers don't appreciate the GOOD staff they have. They'll push five excellent employees out the door, just to get ten mediocre employees on the clock. I've been there for three years, and I'm still treated like I just walked onto the floor yesterday. They take advantage of the good workers, and don't reprimand the ones doing wrong. And upper management keeps saying they support the employees, when they really don't care at all.
Advice to Management: Show a little employee love, and you'll get some back. When I started at CPK, they took care of us. Now we're all disposable.

Title: "Great restaurant if you are comfortable with corporate set goals"
Pros: Flexible hours and commission based pay is what keeps you motivated
Cons: Pay is very susceptible to time of the year

Title: "Great company!"
Pros: Great people, nice managers, room for advancement
Cons: Hard work in the hospitality industry

Title: "Great all Around"
Pros: Working at CPK is like working with a family. They really like to hear employees' ideas and try to get input from all levels of employees to improve the workplace.
Cons: It can take awhile to move up to management if that's what you're there for.

Title: "It has been a long 3 years."
Pros: You can make decent money serving. Usually, at least with my store, it is a relaxed dining atmosphere where employees can relax at their job.
Cons: Too many changes and poor wages for all others than servers. Benefits are terrible too. I have stayed with the company as long as I have due to I am comfortable and have established a spot within my store.
Advice to Management: Stop making the front of house the scapegoat of why the restaurants are doing terrible.

Title: "Great Company"
Pros: Solid corporate culture with opportunity for growth.
Cons: Senior management should more closely review the effect and impact of store managers.
Advice to Management: Keep up the good work.

Title: "Server"
Pros: Good training for servers to gain an understanding of the entire business and what they are trying to sell.
Cons: Poor/biased management that created an edgy work environment and did not trust employees.

Title: "Fun, fast pace environment"
Pros: CPK is a great place to work at for college students because its a relaxed environment and the majority of the people who work there are young and fun.
Cons: Sometimes the managers didn't always accommodate schedules

Title: "Easy to work for."
Pros: easy hours, easy people, good pay.
Cons: customers can be a little rude.

Title: "Leave no stone unturned."
Pros: Never a slow day. You will always keep busy and the time does fly by.
Cons: They have come a long way from where they were. Successful company for many years and now they have changed EVERYTHING to try and get this back.
Advice to Management: Keep things fresh and simple. Don't open up to too many options, tools, charts, etc.

Title: "Great atmosphere until new management arrived."
Pros: Work-life balance was wonderful - company was flexible. However, there were times when others took advantage of the flexibility and abused taking time off. Management would not address certain individuals causing misgivings about how some were treated vs. others who did not take nearly as much advantage in a similar situation. Overall work-life was good.
Cons: There was a lot of favoritism - if you brown nosed enough to certain people, you were in. There were some raging alcoholics, harassers who were promoted and praised. Prior to new management, co-founders were volatile and unpredictable and did not value loyalty. They and other upper management would portray that they valued employees, but they were clearly in it for themselves.
Advice to Management: I can't speak about current management, because shortly after acquiring CPK the layoffs began.

Title: "Loved working here, it has been a great experience"
Pros: flexible work hours, supportive staff
Cons: communicating changes, lack of innovation, extremely high pricing
Advice to Management: Work on communicating with employees better.

Title: "Job was not what I expected"
Pros: The managers are given a dining out card to use on their friends and family. The only thing that you are unable to purchase is alcoholic beverages.
Cons: Work life balance is preached but not practiced, while in training there is only 10 hours a day for the trainee to work. I found myself consistently working 12-13 hours and when I would get ready to leave upper management would say "leaving already?"
Advice to Management: Practice what you preach and when a trainee asks questions help them out don't say you don't know or tell them to go read the book!

Title: "Used to be great. Now its all about money and nothing is good enough."
Pros: Management pays well, but its still not worth it.
Cons: All the new management is about the bottom line and doesn't care about any of the people. They lie to your face while they take away all of your benefits. Several managers worked over a year without a single vacation (RP never approved).
Advice to Management: Get out before its too late. They will sell the company. That is what Golden Gate Capital does. Its all about making money for shareholders. Has nothing to do with food quality, hospitality, or cleanliness anymore.

Title: "Nice Management, Horrible Training System"
Pros: The managers are nice, and everyone who worked there was pleasant. Their training system is tried and true.
Cons: Their training system is a huge problem. It is only made for people who can read - and only read - in order to learn. There is no video substitution or anything, and they expect you to learn 75% of the menu in a week. They will tell you that's not the case, but don't listen - it's exactly the case.
Advice to Management: Realize that there is more than one to learn. For instance, some people are visual, some learn by doing, and others learn by listening. Make it accessible to all, not just the select few who can adapt to *your* way of learning.

Title: "Changing away from employee satisfaction"
Pros: The money can be great especially when you have seniority. There are opportunities to grow within the company so it is a great career path for a driven person without an education.
Cons: CPK has changed the work environment greatly. 8 years ago I was so impressed and then ownership changed. The employee satisfaction is no longer a concern. They have cut benefits and pay and let the employees know they are disposable. Cleanliness is no longer a concern because they don't even want to pay employees long enough to clean. They are so concerned with making every penny they can they are losing respect of their own employees and their patrons!
Advice to Management: Remember where this company started. It had a solid reputation and good customer feedback. Stop ruining a good thing!

Title: "Good money bad work environment"
Pros: Easy work and the tips are good. Hours are decent for a restaurant.
Cons: Unprofessional work environment with too many personal relations between employees and managers

Title: "Host to server"
Pros: CPK has a great company ethic, I have been with them for a couple years and I still go back and miss it. High energy, great environment, and awesome food.
Cons: Mobility is contingent upon others phasing out
Advice to Management: Keep up the great training

Title: "Great concept and discounts of food"
Pros: The discounts on food were great and allowed you to order and try new things. Expensive for what you got but with the food discounts, it was great to eat there at a discount.
Cons: Too much change and senior leadership needs to be consistent. Too much favoritism and not consistent between departments. There was severe favoritism amongst the senior staff and at the Corporate office.
Advice to Management: Too many things to properly address

Title: "Great work atmosphere! I have worked at CPK for 5 years."
Pros: The opportunities for social interaction, networking with regular customers, moderate income, freedom in creating your own style of working as well as flexible hours.
Cons: Rude customers, high stress work environment at times, mismanagement by corporate level in recent years.
Advice to Management: GJ is doing a good job so far, the need to focus on repeat customers is a necessity.

Title: "Waiter"
Pros: Fun, talented, and organized staff. Had the Opportunity to work for California Pizza Kitchen around the Boston area. All of the California Pizza Restaurants that i have worked at had a very good staff. Managers are very knowledgeable and most will do what they can for you.
Cons: Chain restaurant that does not offer a variety of food. I feel like some major Restaurants like the one located at the Prudential center should have the ability to tailor the menu's to suit each city. Customer ask's what's your soup of the day? Server's only response is we only have two soups that haven't changed in the past 2+ years that come pre made in plastic bags, grossâ€¦
Advice to Management: Let your manager's have less restraints on tailoring the menu!

Title: "Started out great, declined over the last year with new CEO who just doesn't get it."
Pros: fun co workers,location was convenient. Customers were pleasant.
Cons: constantly changing schedule, no respect for employees, constantly changing menu (customers don't like that), not enough hours. When I first started the company cared about its employees and treated them like partners in the customer service model. Over the last year with the new CEO really taking over the company has made changes and not for the better. All the perks of working for this company are gone. Long time employees who have loved CPK for a long time are no longer happy and submitting resumes to change jobs. That speaks volumes for the environment. Nobody would change jobs after 10-15 plus years unless its just a necessity. But that is happening. Unhappy employees and management does not care. General Manager will tell you that his concern if for his restaurant and customers. While I do understand what he is trying to say, his manner of conveying information comes across like he does not care about his employees. Its a partnership and CPK would do well to remember that happy employees, equals happy customers, equals happy management and a happy bottom line. Its a balancing act and this company has lost its balance
Advice to Management: Take a look at your business model and realize that employees, customers and businesses all form a partnership and must work harmoniously. Perhaps ask employees what they think and realize you have human being working for you. Stop treating them so badly. The economy forces them to stay but if there were more jobs the employees would have left by now.

Title: "Spiraling down, unfortunately."
Pros: Great benefits. Great opportunity for a manager to learn how to balance FOH & BOH duties. Wonderful standards for cleanliness and food freshness.
Cons: Lack of focus. Cutbacks in quality for guest service. Admittedly, my local regional manager was a great example of the Peter Principle.
Advice to Management: Push managers in their strong areas while making their weak areas the bridge to advancement and not the reason they dread coming to work.

Title: "good place to work, great co-workers. corporate needs help."
Pros: the people i work with are amazing and extremely fun. a very diverse group of people who know how to have fun at work while pleasing guests.
Cons: upper management doesn't know what they're doing. constant menu changes, many employee benefits have been taken away. the upper-management seems to constantly change and just seems very unstable. also, we cater to very large parties and in the near future all restaurants are doing away with gratuity, so when that $300.00+ or $400.00+ bill comes, you better hope they know tipping procedures.
Advice to Management: be consistent, know you customer and give them what they want, not what you think they'll like, and stop taking away great things from the menu only to replace them with items that are likely going to be done away with!

Title: "Great Place to work in College"
Pros: Clientele was wealthy, good tips
Cons: Very corporate, no room for growth
Advice to Management: Each store as unique needs

Title: "GJ Hart has no heart and along with his Texas Roadhouse team he's ruined a great company!"
Pros: Gj throws million dollar conferences, he knows how to party.
Cons: GJ doesn't do what he says he's going to do. He told us trust is earned as he recruited from Texas Roadhouse to replace many of us that helped build the the company. Some needed to go but many were fired with no documentation. The Regional Partner from 2012 was awarded that title in March 2013 and fired in October 2013. He granted options to Regional Partners claiming he was sharing in the upside. As people were let go they were told by Brad Gramlich that the options they owned belonged to them. That when there was a qualifying event they would be evaluated and paid out. Well...the options were evaluated and paid out at $0. CPK made $70,000,000 in EBITDAR and GJ makes over $2,000,000 a year and my options are worth $0 a share....so much for the past 20 years. We have an operators conference at the Ritz Carlton that costs over $1,000,000. We have rolled back wages for FOH and soon BOH employees. We have squeezed labor and reduced manager bonuses. The company has lost its diversity and now is turning into a good old boys club.
Advice to Management: Be honest, do what you say you're going to do. Remember trust is earned. It's very disappointing this company use to care about the people and now it's all about GJ's pockets and sharing the upside with your Texas Roadhouse boys. Brad Gramlich should not be running "the people department". Kim Boerema is the worst COO.

Title: "Great start, slow steady decline."

Title: "Use to be a great company"

Title: "Amazing Place to Work!!"
Pros: I have worked in both the restaurants and at the Restaurant Support Center, and I can't say enough good things about CPK. It was like a family in the restaurants; the hours were great for being in school, and the training was intense to set you up for success. At the RSC, the culture is no less awesome. The CEO (GJ Hart) has made some amazing changes to the company in the last 2 years. Before he joined our team, it was still a great place to work, but things had become comfortable and we weren't pushing the envelope as a forward thinking company like we used to. That has totally turned around; we are changing our look in the restaurants and even hand tossing all of our pizza dough now! We are still a corporation and sales are our main focus right now (as with any business), but CPK appreciates its employees in good times and in bad. GJ is a great leader and we're definitely going places!
Cons: I really don't have anything bad to say about CPK. We are going through changes to make us better, and with any change there are some struggles. However, I believe in the company and have embraced the changes because they are for the good of the company. I was promoted from within and given the opportunity to prove and make a career for myself because upper management believed in me. I would call myself a success story!

Title: "A great place to work, especially when working around school."

Advice to Management: The quality of this company depends upon your leadership.

Title: "Massachusetts Experience: If I could give the company 0 stars, I would."
Pros:
1.) Better than working retail (but that is almost any job in my opinion).
2.) Your co-workers (that is, only the people on the exact same level as you) generally are friendly and help you when you ask.
3.) The company somewhat tries to establish a culture about working there.
4.) When I worked there, the dress code was pretty easy and fair. I heard it's gotten much more picky at the expense of the employees since I left though.
Cons:
Disclaimer: What I am about to share are a number of reasons why I personally feel this company is a bad employer. Not everyone will have the same experiences as me, but you should be aware of what I experienced. This is not meant as a rant.

1.) Your pay is awful, even though they claim it's "competitive." In fact, I had my pay slashed by dollars per hour while working there. They felt that, as a tipped employee, I no longer needed my fixed hourly wage (the state minimum wage), and that my tips plus a menial wage of $4-6/hour would cover the difference. You could get paid WAY better somewhere else, donâ€™t let them stop you from looking as I did MANY times.

2.) You will sign both an at-will employment agreement and an arbitration agreement - multiple times. I had to sign many legal papers twice while employed there, and there were at least 10-15 pages of legalese between all of the forms I signed (there were others in addition to the aforementioned two). Essentially, this company feels that it's acceptable to fire you whenever they want, and for whatever reason (or no reason) they want. Also, forget about a trial by jury when your life goes bottoms up because you've lost your job for no reason, because you either waive that right or don't keep your job at CPK. Do YOU want that kind of job security?

3.) No sick days, no vacation days. Unless you're in management, don't think about getting a paid sick or vacation day. Ever. I never was offered one, nor was anyone I know that wasn't a manager of some sort unless you count company contests that they conducted. The people who won those were probably the only non-management that got vacation days, and to my recollection none of them worked with me.

4.) Favoritism. You'll hear this complaint a lot with many businesses, but my managers played favorites over the most immature stuff. Yes, the managers do try to form relationships with underlings outside of work (see below), which is EXTREMELY unprofessional and explains why the favoritism exists. I have seen multiple times managers keep servers in the WORST sections of the restaurant over and over, while other managers put some servers in the BEST sections of the restaurant every single time. There was at least one server who quit because they would always get the same awful section every day (maybe they got lucky if the manager who made the floor plan thought they were hot), and I can tell you that it was one of the hardest sections to sit. Also, expect to get disciplined while others donâ€™t despite doing the same thing. That happened CONSTANTLY.

5.) Unprofessional staff rampant. Managers sleep with servers, servers sleep with servers, people seek blatantly unprofessional relationships and make sure to bring it up in front of guests. This has been just SOME of my experience, but I feel that it was a pretty big problem that the general manager (GM) and assistant general manager (AGM) either weren't competent enough to pick up on the relationships (they also both had outside relationships with certain individuals in question) or just blatantly disregarded their existence, not sure what happened there.

6.) Advancement doesn't exist. They say they promote from within. Don't believe it if you hear it, unless you define promotion as going from being a host to being a server. If you wan't professional advancement, look for a job with the corporate office or their call center, but I wouldnâ€™t expect much if any professional advancement without a degree, pure dumb luck, or both.

7.) Scheduling is awful. I wish I could take a picture of my HotSchedules (scheduling app) app on my iPhone as proof. They literally block you from taking anything that MIGHT be a busy day months in advance. No joke. They blocked Black Friday in 2013 almost a year before (I still had access then). Then they blocked Valentineâ€™s Day, Motherâ€™s Day, Patriotâ€™s Day, and any major or minor holiday from being asked for off MONTHS in advance. That also includes any vacation days the local schools might be having because little kids might come in with their families (it's a family restaurant). My scheduling manager made asking for days off extremely stressful. If you are a student, I HIGHLY advise you not work for this company.
Advice to Management: Stop caring about the bottom line and start caring about the hosts, take-out servers, counter servers and general servers that are the reason you actually make money. If they all walked out tomorrow and there were no replacements, you'd be getting ready for chapter 11 pretty soon after.

Title: "New owners are a private equity firm and the greed shows"
Pros: A mid-cost dining experience that was affordable and family friendly, yet still busy and priced well enough that servers could still do well.
Cons:
New owners are the private equity firm Golden Gate Capital, started by former employees from Bain Capital (Mitt Romney's company) and it shows. In the past few months, emphasis on service has degenerated to an emphasis on hard sales. New server reviews are formulated by PPA's or per person average. This isn't calculated by the amount of sales divided by the amount of guests. It is calculated as a point system that punishes the server if your items have low points. For example, if you have a family with two kids meals, those kids meals are worth less than one adult plain cheese pizza. Server sections are designated based on their PPA's as well as scheduling.

We used to be allowed shift meals if we were scheduled to work a double shift (am and pm shift combined) but now we are not. On top of that, we aren't allowed to order food while on the clock nor allowed to take our leftovers home if we do order a meal. If we want to take anything home, we have to pay full cost. This is problematic from an affordability stand point but also that if you are working 11am to 10pm, you can't order food until you're off the clock. However, you also can't order food too late before closing time either. So you have to hope you're tables are finished, your side work is done, and you're off the clock at least an hour before closing time. If you are lucky enough to order food, you can't box the leftovers, but are required to throw the food away. We also have an increasingly limited selection of what we are allowed to order off the menu.

Labor hours are calculated based on a complicated formula that is inconsistent with the realities of a day. For example, say there is constant growth in sales from 12pm until 2pm because of the lunch rush. However, sales and labor hours are monitored and the upper management will reprimand managers because there are still staff on the clock after 2:30. It doesn't take into account that we're not herding guests out the door, to allow the server to get off the clock. There should be more time allotted, more flexibility.

Lastly, this week we found out that hourly employees, not sure if that includes back of the house, but bussers, hosts, and bartenders are having their wages reduced to minimum wage. This is regardless of their tenure or pay. For example, staff members who received $10 an hour or have been with the company for 15 years are as of immediately, receiving reduced wages to $7.25 an hour. It was an extreme shock.

On top of all this, staff are being berated if they have too many work hours. I don't mean overtime, I mean that if they work 20 hours a week, and other employees release their shifts to be picked up, and another employee picks up those shifts, increasing their work hours to 30 or more, they get hassled. This is because if they maintain 25 hours or more a week, they qualify for insurance and an annual "bonus" of about $150 (depending on tenure). If they average less than 25 (for lower bonus or insurance qualifications) or 30 hours, they are disqualified or lose their eligibility.

Changes to the menu, serving portions, cups, cutlery, plates, napkins, etc, have all been replaced with cheaper, smaller items, to allow for less portioning out and reduced costs and most importantly: increased profit. I have had many guest complaints because as they said, things "now feel cheapened".

The company is being squeezed dry for profit at every turn and what was once a great company to work for, with great guests, is now feeling morally depleted and a lack of morale shows.
Advice to Management:
To store managers, I feel sorry for you because i know how much you are being pressured literally hourly, with requests for updates, reports, action plans, and overall corrective measures to increase profit.

To the upper management: you are killing the company. We have many guests who come in multiple times a week, not for special occassions but because they felt it was a welcoming, special place. Now they feel herded and unappreciated. We, the staff feel the same way.

Title: "Moving towards big corporate chain"
Pros: schedule flexibility and good when busy
Cons: becoming like other chain restaurants

Title: "Good place to work, but not great."
Pros:
Fun environment in which to work
Good people (mostly) on staff
Cons:
Some racial issues within staff
Quick to cut hours
Advice to Management: Make employees feel more valued- preaching it is one thing, implementing it on a daily basis is another. The new contests and recently implemented tools for valuing the employees are much better, but there needs to be follow through in every aspect. The hours that are given need to be fair and not so preferential. It becomes problematic.

Title: "Grea!t , fun place to work"
Pros: Flexible hours, possibility of great tips.
Cons: Closing one night, then having to open next morning

Title: "It has been a great opportunity to be part of the team."
Pros: Respect, opportunity, communication, kindness. It's what it's all about.
Cons: At times u can have some guest that really can make ur shift go down hill.
Advice to Management: Great support team

Title: "An O.K. place to work, but the concern for employees is in a downward spiral."
Pros: My coworkers are wonderful people. The financial return is good for the number of hours worked, but the work is definitely hard.
Cons: California Pizza Kitchen was bought about by Golden Gate Capital. Since that transition they have been cutting hours to spend less on labor as well as slashing the benefits offered to hourly employees such as paid vacation hours and free meals.
Advice to Management: Slashing hours and benefits reduced employee moral. As an employee of nearly six years, the only benefit I receive is $3 meals. The work is grueling and at my 5 year anniversary all I received was a card. I have begun to resent the company for bleeding us dry.

Title: "Unrealistic expectations"
Pros: Great brand, awesome name recognition. Fantastic product albeit a liitle over-priced for the ambiance. They like to compare themselves to other chain restaurants like Cheesecake Factory and PF Changs but their facitlities lack the correct ambiance for its price point.
Cons: Unrealistic financial expectations that are applied uniformly to all locations and regions in the US. Average work week is 55-60 hours per week which is fine but you always expected to work form home or on your days off. External marketing is expected to happen largely at the store level without more labor dollars offered to cover your absence in the store.
Advice to Management: Get back in touch with what it means to run a restaurant from an operations point of view for the last 5 years with the huge economic downturn our country has been facing and then ask for my help to turn it around. Its not the same as when you were operators.

Title: "Very, very satisfied"
Pros: One of the best companies i've worked for.
Cons: I have nothing too serious or problematic to say about it.

Title: "Great co-workers, fun, relaxed environment. Good Management"
Pros: California Pizza kitchen is a great place for young people just starting out in the work force. It has a relaxed environment, the majority of my co-workers are fun, good people, and the restaurant's name is well established.
Cons: Sometimes company decisions regarding the addition or removal of certain food items just don't make any sense. Good items have been removed to be replaced by bad ones too often.
Advice to Management: Take more time to observe the work of your employees and their relationships with the guest clientele. I have seen way too many of my excellent co-workers get fired because of a small stupid mistake. I have also seen far too many awful co-workers able hang onto their job for way too long.

Title: "Easy place to make money, the food sells itself."
Pros: The people you work with is what makes CPK a great place to work. The shifts are flexible and if you are willing to work the right shifts you can make a lot of money.
Cons: Beware of secret shoppers. You must follow the perfect sequence of service perfectly with every table in order to do well on a secret shopper report.

Title: "Enlightening"
Pros: Flexible schedule, supportive management, great food, fun atmosphere
Cons: Alot of mandatory tests that you have to past in order to serve.

Title: "Has gone downhill the past couple of years"
Pros:
Flexibility
Great people to work with
Quick and easy job for fast cash
Cons: New CEO who cares more about making money than anything else. It used to be a better company 5 years ago to work for. You have to deal with annoying customers who complain about every little thing. You'll get managers that don't know what they're doing.
Advice to Management: Don't blame employees for everything

Title: "Improving under new leadership."
Pros: The company is undergoing a whole slew of changes at the moment--all for the better. Section sizes are decreasing (a good thing! I'm used to 8-12 table sections) and new uniforms are being released.
Cons: Once the dust settles, we'll see which cons still remain. The managers are overworked and underpaid--the usual restaurant crap.
Advice to Management: Calm down. I've seen managers do some really nasty and illegal things over the years and corporate never does anything.

Title: "Serious Pizza"
Pros: Great staff. Great food. Great times.
Cons: Awful clientele. Area of town is nice, but the oeople are not.
Advice to Management: Treat everyone the same and have same expectations for everyone.

Title: "Great training, but loss of hours"
Pros: Awesome formal training before it opened, tipped out, decent hours at beginning.
Cons: After a few months of working, they decided to hire new people, so many employees (and myself) had hours cut back.
Advice to Management: My managers definitely played favorites, unfortunately. That shouldn't be happening.

Title: "Decent money, bad management"
Pros: Better than making minimum wage
Cons: Management plays favorites, super unprofessional, will change someone's schedule so they miss a shift and then fire them, writes people up for small things like not filling a salt shaker. No appreciation for work done. We had the worst numbers in our region, I believe due to management issues.
Advice to Management: Grow up... this isn't high school. There was one good manager that listened to employee's issues, and the kitchen manager was professional. But most of the management was outwardly rude to employees that they didn't like and would find small reasons to let people go.

Title: "Same social dynamic as a middle school; if you weren't part of the right clique you were doomed to fail."
Pros: The money is fantastic. Paid very low hourly, but you get to keep nearly all of your tips (just pay some out to the cooks and the hostess).
Cons: You are expected to pay for everything you need. The uniforms are very specific and you are not given an allowance or anything. You have to buy all your own shirts, pants, shoes, etc. The dissonance between management and servers is also far too much.
Advice to Management: I see a job as something professional. I did not share personal information unless asked specifically (so a non-answer would be awkward), yet I was reprimanded for how I felt about kids. in any other situation or with other people it would be a non-issue. But managers have far too much leeway and if they have a personal opinion about you that is negative, it affects how they treat you. My advice? train your managers to be more professional.

Title: "Fun place to work, don't get stuck."
Pros: California Pizza Kitchen hired me with minimal experienced and gave me pretty extensive training. I made decent money and the food is good, however most of the people there were in college and we didn't take it too seriously. As long as you take it for what it is, it'll be the best time of your life, and there is a pretty close group of servers, at least at my restaurant.
Cons: My restaurant didn't have a very good employee meal programs but that varies between stores. Be wary of lifers and people who take their job too seriously otherwise it'll be fun.
Advice to Management: Take the job a little less seriously and give servers a little bit more room.

Title: "Worked with Fun People, Good Environment"
Pros: The people I worked with in the same position (waiter, counter server) were great. They were willing to help me out if I helped them. Many of them were in similar life situations (just graduated college, trying to get a job). I made a lot of good friends.
Cons: Management often rewards the people that "sell" according to their Steps of Service rather than the people that turn tables quickly with satisfied customers. Often, the servers who did the Steps of Service had others running their food and filling their tables' drinks, as the customers weren't well attended to. These folks tended to get swamped, because they were good salesmen, but poor service professionals. I think rewarding servers on their overall sales for the evening would be a better goal. Also, the location I worked at didn't have very many customers - management should have looked into more effective customer acquisition strategies.
Advice to Management: Concentrate on the customer.

Title: "CPK is a great place to work, dealing with cheap customers? Not so great..."
Pros: They are very good about giving you the schedule you need to live your life. The number one rule is "Make CPK a great place to work" and it is.
Cons: As a server your income is mainly tips, you must depend on the public to tip you. Most tip 15-20%, but some don't (especially in this economy). When the company runs a promotion, giving the customer a discount, your tips go down. People don't tip on the original total and the company doesn't reccomend or suggest that they do. The servers have a problem with that. Other restaurents inform customers that gratuity isn't included in promotions.
Advice to Management:
Every promotion should clearly state gratuity isn't included. Restaurant.com coupons clearly state "Please remember to tip you server on the full value of the guest check."

Strong servers and/or servers with seniority should be given a raise in their hourly wage as well.

Title: "Overall great experience, but depends on your individual manager at each outlet"
Pros: The team was friendly. Food provided was great
Cons: Some managers feel the need to belittle their foreign employees
Advice to Management: Periodically review some of the management team please

Title: "The Perth location is a circus"
Pros: Meeting other servers, bartenders, hosts. They hired a really great bunch of people.
Cons: Management. They drink on the job, are unapproachable, blame the staff for anything and everything, break their own contract rules (no eating upstairs but they eat upstairs), they didnt pay us for the first 4 weeks we worked there, they dont pay their accounts for their bar suppliers so were always out of stuff, dont give proper training cuz they dont know what they're doing themselves but will be the first to blame all the other staff, dont support their staff in any way possible or give them any benefits (not even free food after making them work long hours), for the first 3 weeks of opening nobody got any breaks.
Advice to Management: Don't open up the second store just because your contract says you have to when you cant even handle one store

Title: "A fun environment with lots of potential to grow."
Pros: Promotion is highly achievable if you work hard for it.
Cons: New hires rarely happen since turnover is very low.
Advice to Management: Give employee meals back... (not the worst thing though)

Title: "Solid part-time work environment"
Pros: Steady clientele, easy to transfer in-between locations, supportive management. A great job to have if you're working part-time or still in school.
Cons: Pressure to upsell, corporate environment. Harder to get hours for benefits such as free health care if you are working (or trying to work) full time.

Title: "My experience might have been atypical from others"
Pros: Lots of people go, so servers make a lot of money.
Cons:
-Management and corporate depend too much on statistics concerning their server's ability to sell specific items (like dessert, a beer, a specific type of wine, etc), which made for a stressful work environment.
-When I worked there the restaurant was brand new and servers often had to deal with a slow kitchen because back of the house workers were constantly quitting.
Advice to Management: Keeping your workers happy = successful restaurant.

Title: "Good restaurant to learn about all restaurant activities"
Pros: Excellent opportunity to gain overall experience
Cons: Needs more diversity in staff
Advice to Management: Improve managerial skills in managers

Title: "Badly organized, cocky managers who don't know how to do their job"
Pros: Cool co-workers, everyone is getting along with each other perfectly, made great friends
Cons: Management team is horribly under qualified.
Advice to Management: You train your restaurant staff perfectly. Please invest just as much into training your FOH managers and GMs because most of them have no idea what they are doing. Chaotic and unorganized
